bibl.title: Letter from R.A. Amador to Jefferson Randolph Kean, April 5, 1925

div1.p: Amador congratulates Kean on his review of the Gorgas biography. He discusses his own plans to write a popular history of the yellow fever story for Panama.

div1.head: Letter from R.A. Amador to Jefferson Randolph Kean, April 5, 1925
div1.opener:
FROM GEN. J. R. KEAN
LEGACION DE PANAMA
PARIS
Paris, April 5th.1925.-
from Dr Amador
Col. Jefferson R. Kean.
Medical Corps U.S. Army. (Ret)
Washington.
D.C.
Dear Colonel Kean:
div1.p:
I have read in the “Army and Navy Register” of
March 14th. a very interesting article concerning the “Life and Work
of General Gorgas”. It has been a great pleasure for me to see that
you recollect the fact that our distinguished and never forgotten
friend, Major Walter Reed, was presented for the Christmas tree, “a wonder-
ful stegomyia made of champagne cork with formidable prebosis, and tooth
pick legs beautifully banded, while Dr. Amador, the Post sanitary officer
received a can of kerosene as his badge of office with doggered verses
describing the pursuit of the mosquito”.-

I have always considered that it was a great honor and a lucky
event for me, to have been at Columbia Barracks, under your command and
while the late Major Reed was trying to solve the problem of yellow
fever. During these past years, I have never failed to call the atten-
tion to the fact, that in my humble opinion, Major Reed's work has not
been appreciated in its full value, not by the medical world, but by the
people. General Gorgas' name is all it is known and there are thousands
who don't even know Reed's name.- General Gorgas did a great work but
Reed was really “the man behind”.

I intend to write a pamphlet for the people of my own country,
Panama, who more than anybody else, have received the benefits of Reed8s
-2-
FROM GEN. J. R. KEAN
work, to show them what part our beloved friend took in the matter.

As I will write for the people, that is, for the public in general,
I shall leave aside all technical information; however, it will be use-
ful for me to have certain documentation and to know a few facts con-
cerning the history of Reed's work.- Of course, I know all the techni-
que which was practiced during the experiments etc. and I simply would
like to know a few things, in the same order of ideas as the incident
of the stegomia made out of champagne cork and the kerosene can pre-
sented to me.-

By the way, do you know the whole story concerning the “X.Y.”
case?.- Do you remember that this man was in the receiving ward at Co-
lumbia Barracks, the ward that I had under my charge?.- Do you remember
when I made the diagnosis of yellow fever, without knowing that this
man, who I remember perfectly well, was suffering from a broken femur?.

Do you remember when I told Major Reed my diagnosis and he called
Guiteras, Finlay himself, Lainé and the rest of the “Yellow Fever Board”
in Havana, who all confirmed my diagnosis?.- If you do, my dear Colonel,
I would like you to write to me recalling all these facts.- You are one
of the few who are in a position to know all these facts, and it will
be a great pleasure for me to to have a confirmation from you. I, like
yourself, I am retired from the medical active work, but I always look
back at the time when I was at Pinar del Rio, and later at Columbia
Barracks under your command.-

I have been told that Prof. Howard Kelly has written something
in which he mentions my name. Could you tell me the title of his book?.

Pardon me for taking your time but if I do so is taking advantage
of the esteem that I always had for you,-
div1.closer: Yours very sincerely R. A. Amador.
